Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Dielectric Coating of MEMS Deformable Mirrors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will demonstrate the ability to coat a microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) deformable mirror (DM) array with high-reflectance dielectric coatings. Micromachined DMs provide unprecedented control over an optical beam, however, they cannot sustain operation with lasers of more than a few hundred milliwatts because of the relatively low reflectance of the typical metallic optical coatings. The dielectric coated MEMS DMs developed with this research will be able to handle tens of Watts of laser power commensurate with many laser machining applications. Normally, a dielectric coating would render a MEMS based mirror useless because residual stresses in these thick coatings warp the mirror surface. Even simple single-wavelength coatings with 99.75% reflectance are relatively thick (3-5 times the wavelength of interest) compared to typical MEMS layer thicknesses. To achieve a high-quality mirror surface, this research will fabricate novel MEMS DMs with a stress-compensation layer that balances residual stresses from the dielectric coatings. The stress compensation layer enables the DMs to be coated with well-established and readily available coatings. Mirrors with these coatings will be tested at high laser fluence to determine failure points and validate thermal models of the DM.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to enhance the capabilities of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) deformable mirrors (DM) to make them suitable for use in industrial applications. Deformable mirrors offer high-resolution control of an optical beam spatially and temporally. This ability has led to tremendous technical and scientific advances in astronomy, retinal imaging, and microscopy. The research here will expand the capabilities of low-cost MEMS DMs to provide exquisite wavefront control to applications where relatively high power (1-100 W) lasers are employed. For astronomers, the DM will be used to pre-compensate laser guide star beams for atmospheric turbulence to improve AO performance of 10-30m class telescopes. These increases in performance will enable astronomers to probe deeper into the universe. The same technology can be employed to enhance laser-machining equipment for the electronics and semiconductor industries. Applications for this equipment include via drilling for ceramic packages, through- silicon vias (TSV), laser machining of high-density flex circuits, integrated-circuit trimming of resistors, and cutting of links in DRAMs. For these applications, the DM can provide fast focus corrections and on-the-fly beam shaping to tailor the beam for the task at hand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I project demonstrated the application of dielectric optical coatings on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) segmented deformable mirrors (DMs). High reflectance coatings are required for high-power laser systems, but have not been successfully used on MEMS DMs because residual stresses in the thick dielectric coatings warp the mirrors. This work overcomes this problem by using a hybrid MEMS structure in which the actuator and optical surface are fabricated separately and then flip-chip bonded together. This novel structure uses thick, rigid single-crystal silicon mirror segments to reduce bowing. Further, a stress compensation layer was deposited onto the back side of the mirror segments before final assembly to match stresses in the dielectric coating. Preliminary measurements with aluminum optical coatings survive power levels of nearly 95 W/cm2, but deform excessively because of power absorption in the ~90% reflectance coatings. This research demonstrated that high reflectance (99.85%) dielectric coatings can easily reach 150 W/cm2 power levels using off-the-shelf packaging with only λ/40 degradation rms in mirror surface figure. By adding good heatsinking, the DMs can operate at 1400 W/cm2

with only a λ/40 degradation rms in mirror surface figure.

Deformable mirrors are an important enabling technology in high-precision optical systems. They provide the ability to modify an optical wavefront spatially and temporally. Traditionally, they have been used to provide adaptive optical (AO) correction in order to remove effects of atmospheric turbulence in astronomy, defense imaging, and laser communications systems. In retinal imaging systems, they have enabled in vivo 

imaging of cone photoreceptors because of 3-5 fold increases in resolution by correcting for aberrations inherent in the eye. DMs are well suited to the dynamic modulation of lasers used in manufacturing and research systems. Needs identified by our customers and academic collaborators include: (a) Laser micromachining including trimming of semiconductors, via drilling in high-density interconnects, as well as cutting and scribing of flat panels and photovoltaic cells where MEMS DMs are a compelling alternative to large and expensive moving lens assemblies. (b) Coherent combination of a large number of fiber lasers to achieve compact, high-field laser sources used in particle acceleration and medical research; and, (c) Uplink pre-compensation for laser guide starts used in astronomy where MEMS DMs enable use of lower power lasers and are a cost-attractive alternative to large non-MEMS DMs. Moreover, this research will more generally advance the state-of-the-art in optical MEMS fabrication by demonstrating the ability to deposit dielectric coatings onto large mirrors using a stress compensation layer compatible with existing MEMS process flows.
